user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of _metal_irq_set_enable:
```c
static void _metal_irq_set_enable(int irq, unsigned int state)
{
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;

	cntr = metal_irq_get_controller(irq);
	if (cntr == NULL) {
		return;
	}
	cntr->irq_set_enable(cntr, irq, state);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function _metal_irq_set_enable:
void metal_irq_enable(unsigned int vector)
{
	_metal_irq_set_enable((int)vector, METAL_IRQ_ENABLE);
}
...
void metal_irq_disable(unsigned int vector)
{
	_metal_irq_set_enable((int)vector, METAL_IRQ_DISABLE);
}
...
static struct metal_irq_controller *metal_irq_get_controller(int irq)
{
	struct metal_list *node;
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;

	metal_list_for_each(&irq_cntrs, node) {
		int irq_base, irq_end;

		cntr = (struct metal_irq_controller *)
		       metal_container_of(node, struct metal_irq_controller,
					  node);
		irq_base = cntr->irq_base;
		irq_end = irq_base + cntr->irq_num;
		if (irq >= irq_base && irq < irq_end) {
			return cntr;
		}
	}
	return NULL;
}
...
int metal_irq_register(int irq,
		       metal_irq_handler irq_handler,
		       void *arg)
{
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;
	struct metal_irq *irq_data;

	cntr = metal_irq_get_controller(irq);
	if (cntr == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	if (cntr->irq_register != NULL) {
		return cntr->irq_register(cntr, irq, irq_handler, arg);
	}
	if (cntr->irqs == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	irq_data = &cntr->irqs[irq - cntr->irq_base];
	irq_data->hd = irq_handler;
	irq_data->arg = arg;
	return 0;
}
...
int metal_irq_register(int irq,
		       metal_irq_handler irq_handler,
		       void *arg)
{
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;
	struct metal_irq *irq_data;

	cntr = metal_irq_get_controller(irq);
	if (cntr == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	if (cntr->irq_register != NULL) {
		return cntr->irq_register(cntr, irq, irq_handler, arg);
	}
	if (cntr->irqs == NULL) {
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	irq_data = &cntr->irqs[irq - cntr->irq_base];
	irq_data->hd = irq_handler;
	irq_data->arg = arg;
	return 0;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected fragments that are likely candidates for dead-code investigation: the controller lookup loop, the enable/dispatch helper, and the (duplicated) registration logic. These areas contain conditional paths and duplicate definitions that commonly hide dead operations (e.g. branches that may never be taken, duplicated functions, or code guarded by configuration-dependent pointers).

Why other parts are not included:
- Simple thin wrappers that forward to the helper (e.g. the small enable/disable callers) are straightforward delegations and are not themselves likely to be dead: they only call the underlying implementation with fixed arguments.
- Single-line assignments, local variable declarations, and the final return statements in the shown functions perform observable state changes or return status; without further project context they are necessary and cannot be assumed dead.
- The NULL checks for controller lookup and for irqs pointers implement defensive error handling; these checks are required to avoid undefined behaviour and should not be treated as dead code without evidence they are never triggered.

If more of the codebase (build configuration, controller registrations, or definitions of irq_cntrs and controller initialisation) is provided, further fragments could be added. The fragments reported above are the most suspicious given only the supplied source snippets.
